core_meaning.legge_1899_public_domain: Lü intimates that (in the condition which it denotes) there may be some little attainment and progress. If the stranger or traveller be firm and correct as he ought to be, there will be good fortune.
core_meaning.normalized_summary: Travel and exile. Small success if you’re disciplined, humble, and correct. Guard resources, respect hosts, avoid arrogance, don’t burn bridges; decorum brings good fortune.

translations.text: The first SIX, divided, shows the stranger mean and meanly occupied. It is thus that he brings on himself (further) calamity.
初六：旅琐琐，斯其所取灾。

lines.normalized_meaning: Petty conduct while abroad invites trouble. Keep standards high, even in small matters.

translations.text: The second SIX, divided, shows the stranger, occupying his lodging-house, carrying with him his means of livelihood, and provided with good and trusty servants.
六二：旅即次，怀其资，得童仆贞。

lines.normalized_meaning: Secure lodging, resources, and reliable help. Modest, orderly travel goes well.

translations.text: The third NINE, undivided, shows the stranger, burning his lodging-house, and having lost his servants. However firm and correct he (try to) be, he will be in peril.
九三：旅焚其次，丧其童仆，贞厉。

lines.normalized_meaning: Rash acts destroy your base and allies. Even rectitude can’t spare you from danger now.

translations.text: The fourth NINE, undivided, shows the traveller in a resting-place, having (also) the means of livelihood and the axe, (but still saying), 'I am not at ease in my mind.'
九四：旅于处，得其资斧，我心不快。

lines.normalized_meaning: You’re equipped and sheltered, yet uneasy. Maintain vigilance; don’t relax into carelessness.

translations.text: The fifth SIX, divided, shows its subject shooting a pheasant. He will lose his arrow, but in the end he will obtain praise and a (high) charge.
六五：射雉一矢亡，终以誉命.

lines.normalized_meaning: A small loss precedes recognition. Offer the right token or service; esteem and appointment follow.

translations.text: The sixth NINE, undivided, suggests the idea of a bird burning its nest. The stranger, (thus represented), first laughs and then cries out. He has lost his ox(-like docility) too readily and easily. There will be evil.
上九：鸟焚其巢，旅人先笑后号啕。丧牛于易，凶。

lines.normalized_meaning: Arrogance and frivolity end in ruin. Losing humility turns laughter to lament—misfortune.
